div.p: Greetings in the Lord. I received two letters at the same time and gave a third to Mr. Caelius, who said he had nothing to reply; if he receives any news from Italy, he wishes to share it with you shortly. I also thank you for the news, which we also received; but you write more clearly and add certain things that were not written to us. We are expecting letters from Saxony at any moment. I have shared this with Schertlin and Baron Georg.

The Emperor recently attended mass, I believe on the feast of the Three Kings, and when the priest was reading the Gospel about Herod, he collapsed in the Fugger chapel; the attendants rushed to him, and the priest left the altar in this commotion, running to the Emperor and shouting: "Lord Emperor, invoke Jesus the Savior."
He was lifted up and carried back to his chamber. He immediately ordered his sister Maria, who was then in Ulm, to be summoned to him.
Some think he was struck by an angel of God, as Herod was in the Acts. May the Lord have mercy on him.
You mock me nicely for sending a small gift and receiving a large one. I am a fortunate merchant if I continue to trade this way; soon I will be able to gain more than the Fuggers have.
But this is in jest. Farewell. More soon. You will receive more from the Lord Treasurer. January 19, 1551.
To the well-learned Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, preacher at the Minster in Zurich, my kind lord, to his hands. Zurich.
